text: in 1938 scientists at Harvard University
began what's become one of the longest
running studies ever the Harvard study
of adult development has been tracking
people throughout their lives to find
out what those who live the longest and
stay healthy and happy into old age have
in common the study recruited more than
700 boys some from the University and
some from the local area they ended up
living very different lives and some
went on to do great things President
John F Kennedy was one of the original
members it eventually included wives and
children so the researchers now have
data on thousands of people including
comprehensive information about their
physical and mental health and the ups
and downs of their careers and personal
lives initially the researchers expected
that the most important factor would be
intelligence and good genes but these
turned out not to matter much other
things that you'd expect to play a role
such as diet and exercise had much more
of an impact but there was still
something more important surprisingly
the study found that more than anything
else feeling connected to other people
and having strong social relationships
was the key to a long and healthy life
we underestimate how much of an impact
the quality of our relationships has on
our health and happiness it's easy to
focus on things like what we eat how we
sleep and how often we work out and see
having good social connections as just a
bonus but while these things are
obviously important it's actually the
opposite our relationships with other
people are the foundation of a long and
healthy life solid relationships are
good for our bodies and brain people
with good social connections have
healthier immune systems and are less
likely to get diseases such as diabetes
and heart disease they recover faster
from illness and have lower rates of
depression and as they get older their
mental abilities decline slower the
effect was so powerful that the study's
lead researcher concluded that if he
wanted to predict how healthy someone
would be in old age and how long they'd
live the single most important thing to
know wasn't their income or Fitness
levels but how they felt about their
social relationships the people most
satisfied with the relationships at age
50 were the healthiest at age 80 and
this was true of everyone in the study
not just certain groups another way to
live a happier and longer life is to
incorporate healthy habits which brings
us to today's sponsor ritual ritual is
an obsessively researched and
transparently made multivitamin ritual
helps people fill the gaps in their diet
with no Shady additives fillers or
colorants what product they offer is
essential for men which contains 10 high
quality nutrients such as Vitamin A D
omega-3 and zinc proper levels of these
nutrients are often difficult to get
from your diet alone the delayed release
capsule design is gentle on an empty
stomach and there's a mint tab in every
bottle to keep your vitamins smelling
fresh fill in the gaps in your diet with
essential for men today ritual is
offering 30 off your first month just
click on the link in the description box
below and use coupon code Improvement
pill 30 at checkout thanks to Ritual for
sponsoring today's episode now let's get
back to the topic at hand so why does
social connection affect Health and
Longevity the authors of the study
believe that the lonelier we are the
harder it is for us to recover from
stress when people with strong social
relationships experience stress their
stress levels quickly return to Baseline
levels because they have a friend or
partner or family member to talk to
about their problems and this makes
sense we know how good it can feel to
discuss our problems with someone who
cares about us it's important that these
are people we trust not to judge us and
who we can be ourselves around sometimes
even just knowing that there's someone
in your life who you could call at 2AM
when you're dealing with a problem is
enough to keep your stress levels from
getting too high when Lonely People bump
up against life's challenges they don't
have anyone to turn to or they don't
feel like they do so their body stays in
fight or flight mode and this leads to
chronic inflammation with stress
hormones circulating constantly in their
blood the researchers say that this is
as harmful to our health as smoking or
drinking too much interestingly enough
the researchers found that close
relationships are the most important but
they are not all that matters all
connections help keep us happy and
healthy throughout Our Lives
acquaintances colleagues neighbors even
the dog walker you pass by every morning
or the supermarket worker who you see on
the regular every week when you're doing
your shopping interacting with the same
people on a regular basis is good for
People's Health even if they were not
close connections so how can we
strengthen our relationships well the
researchers said that the key is to
remember that just like physical fitness
we have to put effort into maintaining
these relationships especially today
when there's so many distractions and
when it's so easy to spend all day
binging Netflix or scrolling through
social media you can reach out to a
friend you haven't seen lately to ask
how they're doing and suggest catching
up we often think that other people are
busy and won't want to be bothered but
the truth is that we all like to know
that there are people out there thinking
about us and sometimes people are
lonelier than you realize it's good to
establish routines with friends and
family so that you always see them at
the same time the first Saturday of
every month or every new year for
example without having to make plans our
relationships with the people we see all
that time like Partners or housemates
can also become stale and boring so try
doing something with them that you don't
normally do for instance if you never
take a walk together you could do that
if you want to make new connections
think about joining communities of
like-minded people bonding over shared
interests comes naturally and can often
spark deep relationships you can also
aim to get more comfortable striking up
conversations with people you don't know
though many of us find it scary multiple
Studies have found that talking to
strangers is good for a well-being one
study followed people on their commute
to work and found that those who talk to
someone they didn't know even when they
didn't want to got a happiness boost at
those who just listened to music or
played on their phone didn't the main
takeaway is that we're all different and
we all need different kinds of social
connections some of us are introverts so
we might only need one or two close
relationships but almost all of us need
some and the goal is to find out what
works for you I hope you found the
research and tips useful besides that
guys stay tuned
